title: NSW set for four big batteries in AGL deal
text:
China-Australian firm Maoneng Group will develop four large batteries in NSW underpinned by a 15-year deal with AGL Energy that allows the retailer to call on them as needed and helping compensate for the closure of the Liddell coal power generator.

The announcement of what will be the state's biggest energy storage investment came as AGL chief executive Brett Redman flagged potential major long-term changes at AGL, including a possible move into transport fuels.

Speaking to investors at a briefing in Sydney, Mr Redman also wouldn't rule out a move back into upstream gas production, which would reverse a strategy set by his predecessor Andy Vesey. But he said AGL would prefer to be an equity investor in any gas supply venture rather than an operator, playing down any interest in buying ExxonMobil's 50 per cent stake in the Gippsland Basin joint venture which is for sale.

Maoneng has developed the Sunraysia solar farm in southern NSW. Supplied

Chief financial officer Damien Nicks meanwhile reiterated AGL's guidance for profit in 2019-20, which includes a hit of up to $100 million from the breakdown of a unit at the Loy Yang coal generator in Victoria. He confirmed the unit, which is seen critical for summer power supply, is on track to return to operation on December 16 as scheduled.

Shares in AGL, which is the country's largest power generator and one of the "Big 3" electricity and gas retailers, were down 4¢ at $19.68 in early trading.
description: The batteries will be able to power up to 30,000 homes and be "pivotal" in the transition to clean energy, said AGL chief executive Brett Redman.
